awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: SaTC: CORE: Small: UAV-NetSAFE.COM: UAV Network Security Assessment and Fidelity Enhancement through Cyber-Attack-Ready Optimized Machine-Learning Platforms
awd_abstract_narration:
Unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) find widespread uses in civil, healthcare, and other scientific applications, such as climate monitoring, disaster and pandemic management, merchandise delivery, search and rescue operations, and space exploration. The project UAV-NetSAFE.COM promotes cyber-awareness of UAV networks, pioneers innovative security solutions, and serves the US national interest by directly mitigating the severity of cyber-attacks that could otherwise lead to human causalities, leakage of sensitive data, and degraded quality-of-service. This collaborative project promotes science advancement by investigating a multilayer security framework for the prevention, detection, and mitigation of UAV-oriented cyber-attacks. Also, this project will also impact other areas of high societal interest, such as Internet-of-Things and smart grids. It supports broader education in the areas of cyber-security, machine-learning, and UAV networks by engaging students in educational and research activities such as developing cyber-attack models, evaluating cyber-attacks using machine learning, and designing hardware as well as software solutions for trustworthy networking. Every year, the outcomes of this project will be integrated into existing and new curricula and showcased to attract high school students into STEM degrees. Led by a female lead PI from UND, this collaborative project's educational activities and interdisciplinary research endeavors will benefit Native American students from the state of North Dakota and economically disadvantaged minority and underrepresented students from Chicago metropolitan and NW Indiana. This project is jointly funded by Secure and Trustworthy Cyberspace Program and the Established Program to Stimulate Competitive Research (EPSCoR).
 
The overarching goal of this NSF SaTC collaborative project is to investigate the impacts of cyber-attacks on UAV networks and pioneer cyber-attack-ready platforms. From a software perspective, UAV networks' cyber-attack models will be derived to facilitate UAV-distinctive datasets that aid in the comprehensive assessment and aftermath evaluation of cyber-attack impacts on UAV networks employing qualitative risk investigations and quantitative measures. The resulting datasets will be used to empower UAV networks with both attack detection and decision-making protocols for a range of cyber-attacks by adopting advanced probabilistic and statistical machine-learning algorithms. From a hardware perspective, the PIs will explore software-defined radio setups that intertwine radio frequency beamforming circuit modules with software-based localization and path rescheduling techniques while considering practical constraints such as size and structural complexity. Therefore, the project's key contribution is to pioneer a unified framework that entails cyber-attack evaluation, detection, and countermeasures of software and hardware setups. The PIs will maintain an all-inclusive project website that will help easily disseminate the datasets of cyber-attack models and countermeasure methods to industry and research community to ensure that the proposed framework promotes UAV communication and network security.  This project is jointly funded by Secure and Trustworthy Cyberspace Program and the Established Program to Stimulate Competitive Research (EPSCoR).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

por.por_cntn:
Unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) find uses in civil, military, and scientific applications (e.g., disaster management, search and rescue, space exploration). Key factors that contribute to these uses include the growing demand for autonomous operations and rapid advances in enabling technologies. The goal of this award is to promote cyber-awareness of UAV networks, pioneer innovative security solutions, and serve the US national interest by directly mitigating the severity of cyberattacks that could otherwise lead to casualities, leakage of sensitive data, and degraded quality-of-service.

The first outcome of this project is a comprehensive evaluation of the impacts of cyberattacks on UAV networks based on qualitative risk investigations. To achieve this outcome, the research team established and performed realistic—yet controlled—testing setups of various cyberattacks, including jamming (e.g., single tone, successive pulse), location spoofing (e.g., static, dynamic), and false message injections (e.g., ghost injection, velocity drift). Figures 1–3 show example setups. Then, the team analyzed variations of all cyberattacks for their launch complexity, severity, and likelihood.

The second outcome is datasets of UAV-specific radiometric features extracted from the testing setups. These datasets contain samples with and without the presence of cyberattacks. They were processed to eliminate anomalies, ensure balanced number of samples per class (e.g., authentic, malicious), identify highly correlated features, and discard those with less importance, i.e., dimensionality reduction.

The third outcome is supervised and unsupervised machine learning and deep learning models to detect, classify, and mitigate the cyberattacks. These models were trained and validated with the collected datasets. Furthermore, such models were laboriously evaluated with quantitative metrics including the detection rate, misdetection rate, and false alarm rate as well as other metrics related to time and memory consumptions. Then, they were benchmarked against each other and those with the optimum performance in detecting the cyberattack, classifying its type, and demonstrating merit in mitigating its impact were adopted to engineer the proper countermeasure to each cyberattack.

The fourth outcome is all-inclusive integrated software-hardware solutions, i.e., lightweight platforms, that enable UAVs to specify the presence of attacks and execute countermeasure strategies (e.g., return-to-launch). The platforms operate in real-time without imposing additional hardware components or physical infrastructure. Rather, they benefit the aviation industry with their convenience pairing with existing and legacy technologies. Figures 4–6 illustrate example platforms for detecting jamming, location spoofing, and false message injections, all of which successfully classified incoming transmissions and detected the presence of cyberattacks.

All outcomes were disseminated in scientific venues, including technical journals, international conferences, and workshops, leading to three articles, five proceedings, and at least 10 presentations.

At the educational level, this project provided research experience to at least 30 undergraduate students and five graduate students at Purdue University Northwest through capstone projects and MS theses. More students have been exposed to the project by integrating its outcomes in the courses taught by the PI. Additionally, the project outcomes have been used in outreach activities (e.g., recruitment events, summer camps) to spread cybersecurity awareness among undecided students. Such outreach is expected to attract these students to pursue degrees in engineering or STEM majors.

This project is likely to impact public safety and national security by reducing UAV-related collisions, casualties, and exposure of sensitive data. Furthermore, this project will impact cybersecurity research as it facilitated experimental setups and simulations of cyberattacks as well as qualitative and quantitative evaluations that can benefit researchers to establish their own research and explore potential impacts not only on UAVs, but also on other similar technologies. Moreover, this project will impact the machine learning research as it provided systematic data processing routines and curated datasets that researchers can utilize in boosting their research and precisely training and evaluating their models. In addition, this project has the potential to impact other research areas, including the Internet of Things, Industry 4.0, the transportations industry (e.g., autonomous driving), and smart grids. These areas heavily rely on wireless communications and location awareness; and thus, vulnerable to similar cyberattacks that possibly compromise privacy, knowhow, efficiency, reliability, and trustworthiness (e.g., massive blackouts). This project can inspire real-time anomaly detection solutions, secure authentication, and data-driven insights for ensuring the integrity of interconnected devices. It can also inspire models that lead to improved predictive maintenance, autonomous navigational capacities, and energy infrastructure stability.


Last Modified: 01/17/2025
Modified by: Khair A Al Shamaileh
